title: Geocoding GMD
text:
What happens when household surveys meet geospatial data? The Global Monitoring Database (GMD)‚Äîthe World Bank‚Äôs harmonized repository of household surveys‚Äînow includes geocoded variables that capture the spatial context of interviewed households.
Using a global grid system (H3 hexagons), survey locations are linked to powerful spatial indicators such as population density, urbanization, nighttime lights, accessibility, and climate. Nearly 100 surveys across 44 low- and middle-income countries‚Äîrepresenting about 3 million households‚Äîhave already been mapped to more than 130,000 unique locations.
This integration opens new doors for analysis, allowing researchers and practitioners to combine household data with geospatial insights to better understand living conditions and inform policy.

Using a global grid system (H3 hexagons), survey locations are linked to powerful spatial indicators such as population density, urbanization, nighttime lights, accessibility, and climate. Nearly 100 surveys across 44 low- and middle-income countries‚Äîrepresenting about 3 million households‚Äîhave already been mapped to more than 130,000 unique locations.
This integration opens new doors for analysis, allowing researchers and practitioners to combine household data with geospatial insights to better understand living conditions and inform policy.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
Many tasks in Stata or R/Python can be done more efficiently with support from AI tools (such as Anthropic Claude, ChatGPT, or GitHub Copilot). However, using AI only through a web browser (or Windows Copilot) captures only a small share of its potential.
This first seminar focuses on how microeconomists can use Positron which is an integrated development environment (IDE) designed for data analysis and statistical programming. It is developed by Posit (the company behind RStudio) and is built on Visual Studio Code, but tailored specifically for R, Python, and data-science workflows. In practical terms, Positron combines the flexibility of VS Code with features that are familiar to users of RStudio. This is a very powerful approach that uses World Bank‚Äìapproved development environment that can run Stata or R code directly and integrate AI agents. It also makes AI more ‚Äúaware‚Äù of your working context (your scripts, folders, and outputs), so it can help you write, debug, document, and validate code in a way that is specific to your data and objectives.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
Many tasks in Stata or R/Python can be done more efficiently with support from AI tools (such as Anthropic Claude, ChatGPT, or GitHub Copilot). However, using AI only through a web browser (or Windows Copilot) captures only a small share of its potential.
This first seminar focuses on how microeconomists can use Positron which is an integrated development environment (IDE) designed for data analysis and statistical programming. It is developed by Posit (the company behind RStudio) and is built on Visual Studio Code, but tailored specifically for R, Python, and data-science workflows. In practical terms, Positron combines the flexibility of VS Code with features that are familiar to users of RStudio. This is a very powerful approach that uses World Bank‚Äìapproved development environment that can run Stata or R code directly and integrate AI agents. It also makes AI more ‚Äúaware‚Äù of your working context (your scripts, folders, and outputs), so it can help you write, debug, document, and validate code in a way that is specific to your data and objectives.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
Speaker
Eduard Bukin (ebukin@worldbank.org)
Opening Remarks: Gabriela Inchauste
Series Lead: Maria Eugenia Genoni (mgenoni@worldbank.org)
Moderator: Henry Stemmler (hstemmler@worldbank.org)

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
What You Will Learn
During this first session, we will:

Demonstrate how to use AI assistance in daily coding
Briefly introduce key AI-relevant concepts:

AI-Chat versus AI-Agent
Context awareness and model communication protocol (MCP)
Integrated Development Environments (IDEs): VS Code

Explain the software setup needed to leverage AI agents in analysis:

Positron/VS Code
GitHub and https://github.com/worldbank
GitHub Copilot and access to Claude LLM for coding models

Show step-by-step practical cases of AI application to produce high-quality analysis based on a general task of ‚Äúreproducibility package preparation‚Äù:

How and where to start
Effective prompt generation
Performing analysis
Quality control, validation and preventing hallucinations

Discuss further potential uses of AI-Agents in our everyday work

title: GeoPov
text:
üß† Context Awareness


Positron accesses project metadata. Thus AI ‚Äòknows‚Äô:

üìÅ Files str.: Code, docs
üìä Data: Var. names, types
‚èÆÔ∏è History: Edits, commands
üì¶ Environment: Packages
üéØ Intent: Current task
‚úÖ Results: Output, errors


Why does it matter?

üéØ Project-specific suggestions
üîó Understands dependencies
üõ°Ô∏è Reduces hallucinations
‚è±Ô∏è Improves efficiency

text:

MCP is a universal adapter for AI‚ÄîAnthropic‚Äî that connects data flows:

Stata-MCP or R MCP for Stata/R ‚ü∂ Positron ‚ü∂ Copilot ‚ü∂ LLMs.

title: GeoPov
text:
‚úçÔ∏è Efficient Prompting


üéØ Be specific:
‚ÄúWrite a Stata do-file to ‚Ä¶‚Äù / ‚ÄúRefactor this R function to ‚Ä¶‚Äù
üß© Provide context:
‚ÄúGoal: X; Dataset: Y variables; Constraints: Z (WB rules, packages, runtime)‚Äù
üìå Define expected output:
‚ÄúSave as regression_results.xlsx, format as APA table‚Äù / ‚ÄúCreate bar chart with 95% CIs‚Äù
üîÅ Summarize + clarify first:
‚ÄúRestate and ask clarifying questions before implementing‚Äù, ‚ÄúExplain why ‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúGive alternatives with trade-offs‚Ä¶‚Äù
ü™ú Iterate in small steps:
‚Äúminimal changes‚Äù, ‚Äúrefine‚Äù
üõë Set boundaries:
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt use ‚Ä¶ data‚Äù, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt print secrets, ask if in doubt.‚Äù, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt change files‚Äù.



Tip: Treat the assistant as a collaborator.

title: GeoPov
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations and Remedies

‚ö†Ô∏é Wrong-but-plausible outputs / hallucinations: code runs but logic is wrong
‚úì Verify and validate: ask the model to explain and justify the solution
‚ö†Ô∏é Context limits: not all files/data are in context; too large projects.
‚úì Be explicit: state assumptions, expected inputs/outputs, and references
‚ö†Ô∏é Outdated knowledge: suggested APIs/packages/options may have changed
‚úì Teach the model: provide references/links; ask it to learn
‚ö†Ô∏é Over-reliance: erodes fundamentals; mistakes slip through unchallenged
‚úì Keep learning: ask for step-by-step reasoning; request alternatives and trade-offs
‚ö†Ô∏é Confidentiality / security / privacy
‚úì Constrain context: exclude sensitive data; use .copilot-ignore; AI @ WB
‚ö†Ô∏é Reproducibility: answers can vary across sessions/models/settings
‚úì Cutomize agents: save prompts, use Git; create AI agents


Read more: GitHub Copilot Trust Center | AI @ WB: ai.worldbank.org

title: Maria Davalos
text: Mar√≠a Eugenia D√°valos is a Senior Economist driving analysis and evidence-based policy design to expand economic opportunity and reduce poverty. She has worked across Latin America and the Caribbean and Europe and Central Asia, and brings together analytics and operations on economic mobility, distributional impact of policies and shocks, labor markets, gender, migration, and inequality. In the past few years, Mar√≠a has increasingly focused her work on how place shapes life chances and how spatially targeted solutions can promote more inclusive growth. Her recent policy-oriented research has focused on a geographic lens to inequality of opportunity and intergenerational mobility, and ongoing work on the geography of labor markets and job quality. Beyond her analytical experience, her operational work has leveraged the Bank‚Äôs financing instruments to turn diagnostics into policy reform.

Her recent policy-oriented research has focused on a geographic lens to inequality of opportunity and intergenerational mobility, and ongoing work on the geography of labor markets and job quality. Beyond her analytical experience, her operational work has leveraged the Bank‚Äôs financing instruments to turn diagnostics into policy reform.

title: Eduard Bukin
text:
Eduard Bukin is an experienced economist, data scientist, and statistician spending the last decade at the World Bank, UN, and academia. His career has focused on econometrics, economic research, microeconomics, and statistics, with a strong emphasis on empowering non-specialists to extract insights from complex datasets and effectively communicate analyses through interactive web tools, and artificial intelligence.
Key technical expertise lies in use of the modern data science technologies and programming languages such as R, Python, STATA, and GIS tools. He holds a Master‚Äôs degree in Rural Development from Ghent University and pursues a Ph.D.¬†in Agricultural Economics from Justus Liebig University Giessen.
His research focuses on land and agricultural economics in transitional countries, such as Ukraine and Kazakhstan as well as on economic modelling of trade and climate policies impacts on welfare in developing countries. His work has contributed to several peer-reviewed publications published in the Land Use Policy Journal, Environmental Research Letters, Environmental and Resource Economics and other academic outlets as well as World Bank reports, Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) publications, and internal documents.

title: Projects
text: Our work is organized around three main pillars that guide our approach to integrating geospatial data with poverty analysis.

title: Projects
text:
Our Three Pillars

Spatial Analysis
Applying a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality.


Knowledge and Data Center
Building a curated repository of geospatial data sources and methods for poverty analysis.


Capacity Building
Demystifying geospatial data for microeconomists through hands-on training and peer-learning.

title: Spatial Analysis
text: We apply a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality. Whether it‚Äôs identifying where jobs are (and aren‚Äôt) for the poor, mapping urban deprivation, or analyzing rural income dynamics, we use spatially disaggregated data to generate actionable insights.

title: Spatial Analysis

text:
Our Approach
We work with diverse data sources including:

Household surveys
Censuses

Satellite-based remote sensing

Our analysis covers everything from climate and land use to infrastructure and conflict.

title: Nga Thi Viet Nguyen
text:
A Senior Economist who is passionate about how policies shape people‚Äôs lives ‚Äî and how where they live changes the story. She‚Äôs worked across Sub-Saharan Africa, Central Asia, and the EU, combining solid economic analysis with a growing love for using spatial data to uncover new insights into welfare outcomes.
Her research has appeared in journals like the Journal of Economic Inequality, World Bank Economic Review, and Journal of Development Studies. These days, she‚Äôs especially excited about turning geospatial insights into smarter, more grounded policies that deliver real impact.

Her research has appeared in journals like the Journal of Economic Inequality, World Bank Economic Review, and Journal of Development Studies. These days, she‚Äôs especially excited about turning geospatial insights into smarter, more grounded policies that deliver real impact.

title: Ben Brunckhorst
text: Ben Brunckhorst is a research analyst at the World Bank, where he contributes to the understanding of economic development and policy impact through interdisciplinary work spanning economics, climate change, and data science. He supports global welfare monitoring efforts with a particular focus on subnational spatial disparities in poverty and inequality. With a strong background in development economics and engineering, he utilizes tools such as R and Python to analyze large datasets and extract meaningful insights. His research has been published in academic journals and World Bank reports, and covered by the New York Times.

title: Ben Brunckhorst
text: Ben Brunckhorst is a research analyst at the World Bank, where he contributes to the understanding of economic development and policy impact through interdisciplinary work spanning economics, climate change, and data science. He supports global welfare monitoring efforts with a particular focus on subnational spatial disparities in poverty and inequality. With a strong background in development economics and engineering, he utilizes tools such as R and Python to analyze large datasets and extract meaningful insights. His research has been published in academic journals and World Bank reports, and covered by the New York Times.

title: Henry Stemmler
text:
An Economist by training, Henry Stemmler works on poverty analysis and geospatial analytics at the World Bank. His current work explores how spatial factors shape labor market outcomes and welfare in developing countries, with a particular interest in urban job accessibility and the geographic dimensions of poverty.
He has co-authored World Bank flagship reports including the Poverty, Prosperity and Planet Report, and his work has appeared in journals such as the Economic Journal, Journal of Development Economics, World Development, and Food Policy. He holds a PhD in Economics from the University of G√∂ttingen and previously worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ETH Z√ºrich and as an Economist at the International Labor Organization.

title: Henry Stemmler
text:
An Economist by training, Henry Stemmler works on poverty analysis and geospatial analytics at the World Bank. His current work explores how spatial factors shape labor market outcomes and welfare in developing countries, with a particular interest in urban job accessibility and the geographic dimensions of poverty.
He has co-authored World Bank flagship reports including the Poverty, Prosperity and Planet Report, and his work has appeared in journals such as the Economic Journal, Journal of Development Economics, World Development, and Food Policy. He holds a PhD in Economics from the University of G√∂ttingen and previously worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ETH Z√ºrich and as an Economist at the International Labor Organization.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text: üåç We are a group of development economists and geospatial enthusiasts working at the intersection of poverty, place, and policy. At GeoPov, we believe that where people live matters just as much as how they live ‚Äî and we‚Äôre here to make sure that spatial realities are part of the poverty dialogue.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
üéØ Our Goal
To develop a global agenda that:

Empowers economists by integrating geospatial data and spatial analysis into country-level diagnostics and policy engagement.
Contributes to global knowledge that helps design local solutions grounded in data and spatial context.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
Latest News

Feb 2026: Seminar on AI-Assisted Data Analysis workflow with Positron and Copilot‚Äîmaterials and slides now available in seminars/seminar-2026-02.
November 2025: GeoPov team seminar on Geocoding GMD.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
üß≠ What We Do
Our work is organized around three main pillars:

Pillar 1: Spatial Analysis
We apply a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality. Whether it‚Äôs identifying where jobs are (and aren‚Äôt) for the poor, mapping urban deprivation, or analyzing rural income dynamics, we use spatially disaggregated data to generate actionable insights. This includes household surveys, censuses, administrative records, private sector data, and satellite-based remote sensing ‚Äî covering everything from climate and land use to infrastructure and conflict. We also develop and share open, reproducible code and tools that can be adapted across countries and topics.
Learn more about our Spatial Analysis work ‚Üí


Pillar 2: Knowledge and Data Center
We bring clarity to the what, why, and how of using geospatial data in poverty analysis. This pillar focuses on:

Building a curated repository of geospatial data sources and methods, with clear guidance on how they can (and can‚Äôt) be used in applied work.
Showcasing examples of microeconomic analyses that successfully integrate geospatial data to answer real-world policy questions.

Explore our Knowledge and Data Center ‚Üí


Pillar 3: Capacity Building
We help demystify geospatial data for microeconomists. Through hands-on trainings and peer-learning events, we build core skills for microeconomists to use geospatial methods with confidence. Whether you‚Äôre just getting started or looking to refine your toolkit, we‚Äôre here to support you through our growing Community of Practice.
Explore our seminars and training events ‚Üí

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
üë• Meet the Team
We‚Äôre a global multi-disciplinary team in the Distributional Impact of Policy under the Prosperity Vice Presidency. We combine expertise in microeconomic analysis, spatial economics, and data engineering.
Who we are:

Curious minds who ask ‚Äúwhere‚Äù, ‚Äúwho‚Äù, ‚Äúwhat‚Äù and ‚Äúwhy‚Äù together
Passionate about open data, open code, and inclusive analytics
Believers in the power of maps and evidence to drive better policy

Meet our team members ‚Üí

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
ü§ù Get Involved

Browse our seminars for recordings and materials
Reach out to our team
Report issues or suggest improvements to our code and materials on GitHub issues

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
text:
Answer:
Both integrate well with Git‚Äîyou get the same source control panel, diff viewer, and commit workflow in either IDE. For Git-heavy workflows, you will not notice any difference.
Key differences:

Positron is built specifically for data science, so it includes a native Variables pane, Data Viewer, and Plots panel out of the box
R and Python environment configuration is simpler in Positron (automatic interpreter detection, integrated console)
VS Code requires more extensions to replicate this functionality and integration is less seamless.




Answer:
Not directly comparable. We are not sure if AmazonQ is approved for use at the World Bank, please check with ITS.



Answer:
These tools serve fundamentally different purposes. The latter one is not on coding.



Answer: Yes. Git also could be developed on OneDrive.

Positron only sees files inside your opened project folder unless you explicitly instruct it to look elsewhere
You can keep your Git repository (code, documentation, prompt files) in one location
Confidential datasets can remain on OneDrive, a network drive, or another restricted folder outside the project
Your code references the data path, but the AI assistant never indexes or ‚Äúsees‚Äù the raw data. AI sees the results of your code, not the underlying files, unless you explicitly share them as context.




Answer:
Usage limits come from GitHub Copilot, not from the IDE itself.

If you use the same GitHub account in both Positron and VS Code, you have identical usage limits
The IDE is just the interface; GitHub‚Äôs servers handle the AI requests
WB GitHub is currently on the Copilot Business plan, which offers generous limits suitable for heavy use in data science projects. Use Chat mode for casual use to conserve tokens and Agent when needed.

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 6. How do you download and install Positron?
text:
6. How do you download and install Positron?
Answer:

Installation instructions: https://wbggeopov.github.io/geoPovLearn/seminars/seminar-2026-02/setup-instructions.html
Currently requires IT installation via eServices until Positron becomes available in Software Center
When submitting the eServices request, you will be asked about licensing (see next question)
Could be installed by any ITS associate with software installation permissions. Now it is being tested for being included on Software Center for self-service installation.

Steps summary:

Go to eServices and request software installation
Search for ‚ÄúPositron‚Äù or submit a custom software request
Follow the prompts regarding licensing
IT will install the application on your machine

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 7. Do we have a license and what does it cost?
text:
7. Do we have a license and what does it cost?
Answer:

Cost is $0 ‚Äî Positron is free, open-source software (built by Posit, the company behind RStudio)
When the eServices form asks ‚ÄúDoes your unit have a license?‚Äù, enter ‚ÄúYes‚Äù
This confirms that no paid license is required.

GitHub Copilot is a separate subscription. The World Bank provides Copilot Business licenses. Feel free to reach out to github@worldbank.org

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 8. Can the AI be personalized so instructions don‚Äôt need repeating?
text:
8. Can the AI be personalized so instructions don‚Äôt need repeating?
Answer: Yes, through several mechanisms. Read more positron.posit.co/assistant-chat-agents.html

Prompt Files (.prompt.md): Create reusable instruction files that you attach as context when starting a chat. See: https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/tutorials/customization-library/prompt-files
Copilot Instructions File: Create .github/copilot-instructions.md in your repository root. Copilot automatically reads this file and applies the instructions to all interactions within that workspace.
Agent files (agent.md): For complex workflows, maintain a markdown file describing your project structure, coding conventions, and common tasks. Attach it as context when needed.

Example .github/copilot-instructions.md:

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 9. Does Positron have persistent ‚Äúproject instructions‚Äù like ChatGPT?
text:
9. Does Positron have persistent ‚Äúproject instructions‚Äù like ChatGPT?
Answer: Yes, effectively‚Äîthrough the .github/copilot-instructions.md file.

Create this file in your repository‚Äôs .github/ folder
Copilot reads it automatically for every chat and completion in that workspace
Instructions persist across sessions without manual attachment

This is functionally equivalent to ChatGPT‚Äôs ‚ÄúCustom Instructions‚Äù or ‚ÄúMemory‚Äù features, but scoped to a specific project rather than your entire account.
Limitations:

Instructions only apply within that workspace/repository
Very long instruction files may reduce context available for your actual queries
Keep instructions concise and focused (recommended: under 500 words)

For personal, cross-project preferences, you can also configure Copilot settings in your GitHub account.

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 10. When I ‚Äúalways allow‚Äù terminal commands, is that permanent?
text:
10. When I ‚Äúalways allow‚Äù terminal commands, is that permanent?
Answer: It depends on the scope you select:



Scope
Duration
Risk level




This action only
One-time
Low


This session
Until you close Positron
Medium


This workspace
Permanent for this project
Higher

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 11. Can we set institutional rules so users do not accidentally allow unsafe actions?
text:
11. Can we set institutional rules so users do not accidentally allow unsafe actions?
Answer: Yes, and this is strongly recommended for team environments.
Approaches:

Workspace settings (.vscode/settings.json): Pre-configure which commands are allowed or blocked, then commit this file to your shared repository
Documentation and training: Establish team protocols specifying which permissions are acceptable
Prompt protocols: Check the GPID workflow protocols: https://gpid-wb.github.io/Pip-Technical-Guidelines/copilot_protocols.html
Code review: Require review of any AI-generated code that interacts with file systems or external services

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 12. What if I have confidential data on OneDrive?
text:
12. What if I have confidential data on OneDrive?
Answer: The AI only processes files you explicitly provide as context. Several safeguards help protect confidential data:

Project isolation: AI only sees files in your Positron project folder‚ÄîOneDrive folders outside the project are invisible
Ignore files: Create .copilotignore and/or .aidigestignore in your project root to exclude sensitive files:
# .copilotignore
data/raw/*
*.dta
*confidential*
Folder structure: Keep confidential data in separate restricted folders, outside your code repository entirely
Explicit context: AI only processes files you attach to a chat or that are open in your editor
Anonymization assistance: You can ask the AI to help write code that anonymizes data before you expose any real values

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 13. Can AI only see folders we grant access to?
text:
13. Can AI only see folders we grant access to?
Answer: Yes. The AI has no access outside your Positron project directory unless you specifically direct it there.

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 14. Can the integrated agent fix Stata errors like it does in R?
text:
14. Can the integrated agent fix Stata errors like it does in R?
Answer: Not currently, due to technical and security constraints: WB imposes policy that forbids running MCP servers locally.
Why R works but Stata does not:

Positron has the Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for R that allows Copilot to interact directly with the R console‚Äîreading errors, inspecting objects, and running diagnostic code. It also has it for python.
Stata lacks an MCP implementation, and World Bank security policies restrict the installation of custom protocol servers.
This means Copilot cannot ‚Äúsee‚Äù your Stata console output or automatically diagnose errors

Workarounds:

Manual error copying: Copy the Stata error message and paste it into Copilot chat with your code. The AI can still diagnose and suggest fixes.
Log files: Direct Stata output to a log file in your project folder:
log using "output/analysis_log.log", text replace
Then attach the log file as context for debugging.

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 15. Comment: ‚ÄúData management must come first for AI to be effective.‚Äù
text:
15. Comment: ‚ÄúData management must come first for AI to be effective.‚Äù
Response: Agreed. AI amplifies your existing workflow‚Äîit cannot compensate for:

Missing documentation
Unclear data structures
Inconsistent variable naming
Irregular file organization

Practical implications:

Invest time in READMEs, codebooks, and data dictionaries
Use consistent naming conventions the AI can learn from
Structure projects logically (e.g., data/, code/, output/)
Document your workflow before asking AI to help optimize it

Well-organized projects get dramatically better AI assistance.

title: Q&A: AI-Assisted Data Analysis with Positron
section: 16. Teams should establish prompt protocols to ensure quality.
text:
16. Teams should establish prompt protocols to ensure quality.
Response: Agreed. Standardized prompting improves consistency, reproducibility, and code quality across team members.
Recommended starting point: The GPID workflow protocols provide an excellent foundation: https://gpid-wb.github.io/Pip-Technical-Guidelines/copilot_protocols.html
Key elements of good prompt protocols:

Standard prompt templates for common tasks (data cleaning, merging, visualization)
Required context to include (data structure, variable definitions, expected output)
Review requirements for AI-generated code
Documentation standards for AI-assisted work

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Setup software environment for AI agent-assisted analysis in Stata and R
Enable GitHub Copilot or Claude AI integration
Be able to reproduce AI-assisted coding workflow demonstrated in the seminar

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Overview
To be able to run positron and use GitHub Copilot or Anthropic Claude for AI-assisted analysis, you need to complete the following steps:

Software setup:

Stata, R, Python, Positron, Git > Python package uv > extensions in Positron (Stata MCP, Quarto)

Github account setup:

Create a github account using private email (not WB email).
Join World Bank github organization.
Request GitHub Copilot access from World Bank GitHub organization administrators.

Connect GitHub Copilot to Positron and enable Positron Assistant in Positron settings.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Known Issues and Troubleshooting

If you have trouble installing software from the Software Center, contact IT Help: ITHelp@worldbankgroup.org or use Walk-in center.
If you have trouble with GitHub World Bank or Github Copilot access from World Bank GitHub setup instructions or contact github@worldbank.org.
Github copilot does not work in Positron after installation:

Make sure you set-up Github account properly
Make sure that you have enabled Positron Assistant in Positron settings
Make sure you are signed into GitHub in Positron
Reload Positron after installation and setup: Ctrl+Shift+P > Developer: Reload Window > Enter or close it and open again.

Stata-MCP extension does not run code from the OneDrive.
This is a known issue with Stata MCP extension when running code from OneDrive folder. It happens because our one drive folder has a space in the name (‚ÄúOneDrive - WBG‚Äù). A workaround is to move the code to a different folder without spaces in the path, for example C:\Users\wbXXXXXXX\code, and run it from there. Once this issue it resolved on the Stata MCP extension side, it will update in positron automatically and you will be able to run code from the OneDrive folder again.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Software setup

Step 1. Prerequisite Software: Stata, R, Python
Go to the World Bank Software Center App and install the following software (if not already installed) :









Software
Notes





Stata 19 or higher (latest available)




Positron Latest




R 4.5.2 (latest)




Python 3.13+ (latest)




Quarto 1.3.343 (latest)
May require software installation request



Git 2.52+ (latest)




GitHub Desktop Latest
Optional





Step 2. Install Required Python Package

Open Command Prompt (cmd) or PowerShell:

Press Win + R, type cmd or powershell, and hit Enter.

Type pip install uv and press Enter to install the uv package.

uv is a package that allows environments management in python, see https://pypi.org/project/uv/

Check if UV is installed correctly by typing uv --version in the Command Prompt or PowerShell. You should see the version number displayed, something like this:
uv 0.9.18 (0cee76417 2025-12-16)



Step 3. Install Positron (IDE) from the software center
The positron is now available for installation at the World Bank through the Software Center. No requests or administrative privileges are required. Big thank you to our ITS colleagues for making this possible!


Step 4. Install Extensions in Positron
Extensions are add-ons that enhance Positron‚Äôs functionality. To install extensions, open the Extensions panel by clicking the square icon  on the left sidebar or pressing Ctrl+Shift+X. There are many extensions available for Positron. Below are the key extensions to install for AI-assisted analysis:

Stata MCP
Stata MCP Extension enables Model Communication Protocol (MCP) for Stata, providing better context awareness for AI agents and allowing you to run Stata code directly from Positron.
To install it:








Description





Open the Extensions panel in Positron



Search for ‚ÄúStata MCP‚Äù in the Extensions panel



Click ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù to add the extension to Positron



After installation, restart Positron or reload the window (Ctrl+Shift+P > Developer: Reload Window > Enter)



Once installed, configure the Stata MCP extension by setting up the path to the Stata executable and Stata edition.

Open stata-vscode.stataPath or press Ctrl+, > search ‚ÄúStata Path‚Äù (or stata-vscode.stataPath), and set it to your Stata executable folder: C:\Program Files\StataNow19\ (for most WB laptops and VDIs). 
Open stata-vscode.stataEdition
or press Ctrl+, > search ‚ÄúStata Edition‚Äù (or stata-vscode.stataEdition), and
set it to ‚Äúmp‚Äù for Stata MP version.




Verify Stata MCP is working:

Create and save a new Stata .do file
Type a simple command like: stata     sysuse auto     summarize price     display "Stata is working!"
Press Ctrl+Shift+D in the .do file or Ctrl+Shift+P > type Stata: Run Current File > Enter to run the do file or click on the button 
Results from Stata should appear in the Output panel: Press Ctrl+Shift+P > Output: Show Output Channels... > Enter > Stata. 



Other relevant extensions
Quarto Extension enables Quarto document editing and rendering in Positron.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
GitHub Setup
GitHub setup includes (1) creating a GitHub account, (2) joining the World Bank GitHub organization, and (3) requesting access to GitHub Copilot. These steps can be done independently and give different privileges to users, see table below.



Access Level
GH Permissions
GitHub Copilot / AI Assistance
github.com/worldbank




No GitHub Account
‚ùå No: view public repos only
‚ùå No
‚ùå No (only view public repositories)


Personal GH Account(created at github.com)
‚úÖ Everything: Create personal repos, collaborate
‚ö†Ô∏è Usage limit on all services. No access to Claude
‚ùå No


+ GH Copilot subscription (Copilot Pro or Pro+)
‚úÖ Everything
‚úÖ Unlimited code completion + Chat. ‚ö†Ô∏è Limit on Agent‚úÖ Access to premium models (Claude, GPT-4.5)
‚ùå No


WB Organization Member(join via eServices)
Access WB public and internal repos; Create repos under WB org
‚ö†Ô∏è Limited (depends on GH Copilot subscription)
‚úÖ Yes (view / contribute)


WB Org + Copilot Access(request Copilot via GitHub Settings and email to github@worldbank.org)
‚úÖ Unlimited code completion + Chat. ‚ö†Ô∏è Limit on Agent (300 requests/month)‚úÖ Access to premium models (Claude, GPT-4.5)
‚úÖ Yes (Claude, GPT-4, etc.)
‚úÖ Yes



Key takeaways:

For AI-assisted coding: You need at minimum ‚ÄúPrivate GH account + WB Org + Copilot Access (private Pro subscription or from World Bank GitHub)‚Äù
To be able to use GitHub Copilot with Claude: You need Copilot Access (private Pro subscription or from World Bank GitHub)
Email matters: Always use your personal email, not your WB email, when creating your GitHub account


Step 1: Create a GitHub Account
If you don‚Äôt have a GitHub account yet, create one at https://github.com/signup or read more GH: get-started






Warning



Note: Use your personal email address, not your World Bank email.




Step 2: Join the World Bank GitHub Organization

Submit a ‚ÄúJoin GitHub Organization Account Request‚Äù on eServices to join github.com/worldbank
Once your request is approved, you will receive an email invitation to join the World Bank GitHub organization

Email will be sent to the email address associated with your GitHub account

Accept the invitation by clicking the link in the email

You need to confirm your membership in the World Bank organization on GitHub by following steps indicated in the email.
If you don‚Äôt confirm within a few days, the invitation will expire, and you will need to request again through eService.




Step 3: Request GitHub Copilot Access from World Bank GitHub Organization
After joining the World Bank organization, request GitHub Copilot access. To do this:


Go to GitHub > Settings > Copilot settings.







Scroll all the down to the ‚ÄúGet Copilot from an organization‚Äù section and click the ‚ÄúRequest access‚Äù button from worldbank organization.
Sending an email to github@worldbank.org with the subject line: ‚ÄúRequest GitHub Copilot Access‚Äù. In the email body, include your GitHub username and a brief reason for requesting access. Copy manager or team lead for approval.





Your request will be reviewed and approved by the GitHub organization administrators.






Tip



Tip: Bryan Cahill and github@worldbank.org lead the github.com/worldbank organization and can help with Copilot access requests.








Warning



Warning: If you don‚Äôt see the ‚ÄúRequest access‚Äù button or worldbank organization, it means you haven‚Äôt been added to the World Bank GitHub organization yet. Please complete Step 2 above, wait for the confirmation email, and accept the invitation before requesting access.


Once approved, you‚Äôll be able to use GitHub Copilot in Positron


Step 4: Verify GitHub Copilot Access
In github.com, go to GitHub > Settings > Copilot settings and verify that you have access to GitHub Copilot through the World Bank organization. Your usage statistics will looks like this:


No access to Copilot from World Bank GitHub organization or personal plan Pro or Pro+


Access to Copilot from World Bank GitHub organization or personal plan Pro or Pro+



Another way is to check if you have access to premium models like Anthropic Claude or GPT-4.5 in the Positron Assistant settings (see instructions below).

Open Positron and sign in to your GitHub account (see ‚ÄúConnecting GitHub Copilot to Positron‚Äù section above)
Check that the GitHub Copilot extension is active in the Extensions panel
Try typing a comment in a code file to verify that Copilot suggestions appear

Note: If you have access to GitHub Copilot but don‚Äôt see suggestions in Positron, make sure you are signed into GitHub in Positron and that the GitHub Copilot extension is installed and enabled.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
section: Positron + GitHub Copilot / Anthropic Claude Setup
text:
Positron + GitHub Copilot / Anthropic Claude Setup
This step enables you to use the GitHub Copilot coding agent and other LLMs, such as ChatGPT or Anthropic Claude, with Positron.
See Positron Assistant: Getting Started for the full overview of what it does.






Warning



Warning: Sometimes it is needed to reload Positron after installing software or extensions for the changes to take effect.



Step 1. Connect GitHub to Positron
This requires a GitHub account linked to the World Bank organization. See GitHub Setup [@github-setup] instructions below if you don‚Äôt have an account or haven‚Äôt linked it to the WB organization. To connect GitHub to Positron:








Note





Open Account menu



Click Sign in to your GitHub account



Authorize GitHub in your browser



Confirm the authorization request



Complete the authentication process



Grant necessary permissions







See also Positron Assistant Guide for more details on connecting GitHub and using the assistant.


Step 2. Enabling Positron Assistant in Positron Settings

Open settings positron.assistant.enable and check the box to enable it. or Ctrl+, > positron.assistant.enable > Check the box 
Restart Positron to apply the changes
or reload the window (Ctrl+Shift+P > Developer: Reload Window > Enter) 

See Enable Positron Assistant for more details.


Step 3. Configure LLM Provider
By default, when logged into GitHub, Positron Assistant uses GitHub Copilot as the LLM provider. GitHub Copilot provides code completion, answers questions in chat, and operates in agent mode (able to run code directly).






Warning



Note: Within GitHub Copilot, you can also configure other LLM providers, such as Anthropic Claude, OpenAI GPT, etc.


If you want to use Anthropic Claude or other LLMs as the provider, follow instructions in Configure language model providers.






Warning



Note: Code completion will still be provided by the GitHub Copilot extension or will not work with Anthropic Claude.




Step 4. Using Positron Assistant

Ctrl+Shift+P > Help: Ask Positron Assistant > Enter to open it.
In the input box that appears, type your question. For example: Write a Stata do file that loads the auto dataset and summarizes the price variable.     Open it.     Explain how to run it.

To learn more about using Positron Assistant, see Use Positron Assistant

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Additional Resources

Positron Documentation

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Support
For help with setting up or troubleshooting the software, contact:

IT Help: ITHelp@worldbankgroup.org
HQ Walk-in center

Remember to provide assisting person with these setup instructions.
For help with accessing GitHub.com/Worldbank or Github Copilot from the worldbank:

Check: GitHub Setup instructions above
Reach out to: github@worldbank.org

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Appendix

Positron1 installation instructions, when it is not available in the Software Center

Download Positron from https://positron.posit.co/download.html







Warning



Important: Use ‚ÄúWindows 10, 11 x64 (system level install)‚Äù, not the ‚Äúuser level install‚Äù



Make a ‚ÄúSoftware Installation Request‚Äù on eservice.

Go to eservices/
Select ‚ÄúSoftware Installation Request‚Äù
See KB0076748 for more details.

Once approved, you will have two options to install Positron:

ITS Personnel will connect to your computer remotely and install Positron using an admin password.
You will need an admin password to install Positron yourself.

Either way, follow these installation instructions:

Step 1: Copy the executable (exe) or installation folder to C:\WBG.
Step 2: Launch the command shell (cmd.exe) as an administrator.
Step 3: Navigate to C:\WBG in the command shell.
Step 4: Set the user profile, TEMP, and TMP environments, and launch the executable from the shell prompt by typing:
set userprofile=c:\wbg\temp
set temp=c:\wbg\temp\temp
set tmp=c:\wbg\temp\temp
Positron-20XX.XX.X-XXX-Setup-x64.exe
Note: Replace Positron-20XX.XX.X-XXX-Setup-x64.exe with the actual filename of the Positron installer you downloaded.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Footnotes


Alternatively, you can use Visual Studio Code (VS Code) as your IDE. We encourage using Positron for its better context awareness when developing R/Stata and analysis scripts. VS Code can be installed from the Software Center. Note that some steps below may differ when using VS Code instead of Positron. VS Code does not have many built-in R language features that Positron has out-of-the-box and lacks key bindings relevant to data science tasks.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: GeoPov BBL Series
text:
This webinar series creates a platform for dialogue on how geospatial data can strengthen analysis and policy discussions aimed at reducing poverty and vulnerability. It has two main objectives:

Showcasing impactful applications ‚Äì highlighting country experiences and operational work where geospatial tools have improved poverty analysis, targeting, and decision-making. These cases illustrate models with potential for scaling up and replication in other contexts.
Sharing technical knowledge ‚Äì presenting innovative geospatial data sources, tools, and methodologies relevant for economists and practitioners working at the country level, with a focus on practical skills.

Through these conversations, the series seeks to bridge the gap between cutting-edge technical innovations and their use in shaping policies that can make a measurable difference for the poorest and most vulnerable populations.
Suggestions for future topics and speakers are warmly welcome ‚Äì please reach out to Henry Stemmler (hstemmler@worldbank.org).

title: GeoPov BBL Series
text: Past talks, seminars, and presentations
